text:
# 
Population Size: At mid-2014, the population of Hong Kong was 7.24 million, including 7.03 million Usual Residents and 0.22 million Mobile Residents. 
During the period 2010 to 2014, the population grew at an average annual rate of $0.8\%$ . Population in these years was as follows: 

\begin{tabular}{lll}
\multicolumn{3}{l}{} \\
 & Mid-year & Annualrate \\
Year & ondo & ofincrease 1 000 females) \\
2010 7024200 & 0.7 & 883 \\
2011 & 7071600 & 0.7 876 \\
2012 7154600 &  & 869 \\
2013 7187500 & 0.5 & 864 \\
2014 & 7241700 & 0.8 858 \\
\end{tabular}


Distribution by Area: At mid-2014, the population was distributed geographically as follows: 
Area % of total population Hong Kong Island 17.5 Kowloon 30.3 New Territories (including marine) 52.2 
Total 
Population Density‡: Hong Kong is one of the most densely populated places in the world. The land population density as at mid-2014 stood at 6 690 persons per square kilometre, and Kwun Tong, with 57 250 persons per square kilometre, was the most densely populated district among the District Council districts. 
‡ Excluding marine population and area of reservoirs. 
Age and Sex Structure: At mid-2014, there were 858 males per 1 000 females. The median age of the total population was 42.8. The age and sex structure of the population was given as follows: 
\begin{tabular}{lllllll}
\multicolumn{3}{l}{Male} & \multicolumn{2}{l}{Female} & \multicolumn{2}{l}{Total} \\
Age Group & Number & % & Number & % & Number & % \\
0-14 & 415200 & 5.7 & 389200 & 5.4 & 804400 & 11.1 \\
15-24 & 421400 & 5.8 & 413800 & 5.7 & 835200 & 11.5 \\
25-34 & 457200 & 6.3 & 639800 & 8.8 & 1097000 & 15.1 \\
35-44 & 466500 & 6.4 & 673000 & 9.3 & 1139500 & 15.7 \\
45-54 & 568500 & 7.9 & 679600 & 9.4 & 1248100 & 17.2 \\
55-64 & 519300 & 7.2 & 532300 & 7.4 & 1051600 & 14.5 \\
65andover & 497000 & 6.9 & 568900 & 7.9 & 1065900 & 14.7 \\
Total & 3345100 & 46.2 & 3896600 & 53.8 & 7241700 & 100.0 \\
\end{tabular}


Births and Deaths: Fertility rate in Hong Kong has continued to remain at a low level. It has also attained a very low level of mortality by international standards. Birth and death rates are given as follows: 

\begin{tabular}{lllllll}
\multicolumn{4}{l}{Total} & \multirow{2}{*}{Expectation oflife} & \multirow{2}{*}{Expectation oflife} & \multirow{2}{*}{Infant mortality} \\
 & Crude & fertility & Crude \\
\multirow{2}{*}{} & birthrate & rate & deathrate & atbirth & atbirth & rate \\
 & (per1000 & (per1000 & (per1000 & formales & forfemales & (per1000 \\
Year & (ndo & women) & population) & (years) & (years) & livebirths) \\
2010 & 12.6 & 1127 & 6.0 & 80.1 & 86.0 & 1.7 \\
2011 & 13.5 & 1204 & 6.0 & 80.3 & 86.7 & 1.3 \\
2012 & 12.8 & 1285 & 6.1 & 80.7 & 86.4 & 1.5 \\
2013 & 7.9 & 1124 & 6.0 & 81.1 & 86.7 & 1.8 \\
2014# & 8.6 & 1235 & 6.2 & 81.2 & 86.7 & 1.6 \\
\end{tabular}


$\uplambda$ Total fertility rate refers to the average number of children that would be born alive to 1 000 women during their lifetime if they were to pass through their childbearing ages 15-49 experiencing the age specific fertility rates prevailing in a given year. These figures have been compiled using a population denominator which has excluded female foreign domestic helpers.

The birth rate remained low (12.6 live births per 1 000 population in 2010 to $8.6^{\#}$ in 2014). Moreover, according to the total fertility rate, 1 000 women in 2014 would bear, on average, 1 $23\dot{5}^{\#}$ children in their lifetime as compared with 1 127 children in 2010. 
In 2014, the death rate was $6.2^{\#}$ per $1000$ population. The expectation of life at birth was ${\dot{8}}1.2^{\#}$ years for males and $8\dot{6}.7^{\#}$ years for females, compared against the corresponding figures of 80.1 and 86.0 years in 2010. 
There was a decline in the infant mortality rate from 1.7 per $1000$ live births in 2010 to $1.6^{\#}$ in 2014. The decline reflected a continual improvement in maternal and child health services. 
Education: The educational level of the population of Hong Kong has improved appreciably over the past 5 years. The following table compares the educational attainment of the population aged 15 and over++ for 2010 and 2014: 

\begin{tabular}{lll}
\multicolumn{3}{l}{%ofpopulationaged15andover} \\
Educationalattainment & 2010 & 2014 \\
Primaryandbelow & 22.1 & 19.6 \\
Secondary** & 52.0 & 50.5 \\
Post-secondary & 25.8 & 29.8 \\
Total & 100.0 & 100.0 \\
\end{tabular}

Persons with educational attainment at secondary level refer to those with Secondary 1 to Secondary 7 education or equivalent level.

# 
Labour Force Participation Rate: The size of the total labour force in Hong Kong for 2014 was 3.88 million. This represented $61.1\%$ of the total population aged 15 and over++. The following table shows the labour force participation rates of the population by age and ${\mathsf{s e x}}^{++}$ : 

\begin{tabular}{lll}
Age group & Male (%) & Female (%) \\
15-19 & 11.1 & 12.5 \\
20-24 & 61.5 & 61.4 \\
25-29 & 93.4 & 86.3 \\
30-34 & 96.6 & 81.5 \\
35-39 & 96.4 & 76.4 \\
40-44 & 95.7 & 73.7 \\
45-49 & 93.8 & 72.4 \\
50-54 & 91.8 & 64.2 \\
55-59 & 81.4 & 48.8 \\
60-64 & 56.2 & 26.2 \\
65andover & 14.3 & 3.7 \\
Overall & 68.8 & 54.6 \\
\end{tabular}

There may be a slight discrepancy between the sum of individual items and the total as shown in the tables due to rounding. 
# Provisional figures. 
$^{++}$ Figures are compiled based on data collected in the General Household Survey from January to December of the year concerned as well as the mid-year population estimates by District Council district compiled jointly by the Census and Statistics Department and an inter-departmental Working Group on Population Distribution Projections. The General Household Survey covers the land-based non-institutional population of Hong Kong.
